In reading Sasano, I see that he frequently speaks of the color of a 
given=
 tsuba as being indicative of its age/period, as well as of the 
qualitativ=
e aspects of its iron.  However, he tends not to elaborate 
on this, and si=
nce the images are virtually entirely in black and 
white in the two well-k=
nown English language texts on sukashi tsuba, 
it is difficult to actually =
see what he means when he makes such 
comments.  A few times he does note t=
hat Momoyama Kanayama tsuba tend 
to have a reddish cast to them (as well a=
s being smaller) when 
compared to Kanayama guards of earlier times.  I was=
 just wondering if 
this is the consensus among those of you who have much =
experience with 
Kanayama tsuba.  If so, is it enough to conclude that such=
 
characteristics are so consistent as to be understood as definitive of 
t=
he period?

Steven
